After colliding with the sculpture, assesses himself for injuries and confidently states he has no broken bones.
Navigates to the bed using the wall and his hands despite being in the dark and disoriented.
Acknowledges the failure of the relationship clearly and decisively; quickly packs up and leaves without hesitation.
Expresses emotional vulnerability and frustration in a composed manner rather than lashing out or panicking.
No indication of hasty or reckless behavior despite disorientation; moves carefully and methodically.
Seems to lack forward planning or diplomatic communication to possibly salvage the relationship; abruptly leaves after assuming Amy’s silence is refusal.
Holds her back gently and compliments her beauty.
Stares silently at family photo, showing restrained emotion and possible unresolved feelings.
Requests to be left alone when tired, showing distance and reluctance to engage.
Apprehensive about the phone call but does not confront it, displaying avoidance.
Walks around his sparse home observing it with quiet reflection, indicating introspection more than warmth.
Observes his old town with a sense of alienation and disturbance, showing emotional distance.
Walks around his home observing details and reflecting on his family photo, showing awareness and introspection.
Expresses need to be alone when tired, setting boundaries calmly.
Does not answer the phone despite ringing multiple times, showing hesitation and apprehension.
Walks through his hometown, observing changes and reacting with visible disturbance, indicating thoughtful perception.
Follows sister's lead in letting her answer the phone instead, showing passivity in a possibly important moment.
Stands silently looking at places and memories that once meant a lot to him, reflects quietly on lost magic and his changing world.
Sits alone in the library, rapidly absorbing images of life, beauty, and horrors of the world with a face filled with anguish.
Closes his eyes and listens carefully, cocking his head to each side, showing perceptive and attentive behavior.

Sits in the library and rapidly flips through stacks of LIFE magazines, absorbing a wide array of important historical and cultural images, indicating intellectual curiosity and a methodical approach to understanding.
Stares at a building he's never seen before and never been inside, indicates openness to new experiences but lack of prior knowledge.
Shifts furniture with purpose and evaluates the arrangement carefully.
Demonstrates critical thinking by challenging Jennie's limited view of the world beyond Main Street.
Expresses insight into the limitations imposed by others and pushes for a broader understanding.
Persists in seeking knowledge despite physical and emotional pain caused by recent sight experiences.
Displays emotional vulnerability and dependence on Jennie to keep his safe world intact.
Reaches out his arms for Jennie, inviting her to join him, showing openness and emotional support.
Says 'I'm reaching out, Jennie,' demonstrating sincerity and a desire to connect.
Encourages Jennie to accept herself and reach out with confidence, offering support and emotional strength.
Shows confidence and decisiveness in emotional interactions, leading Jennie to respond positively.
Walks the path with Sophie closely following, indicating trust and patience.
Stands silently observing the sunrise and his fading vision without complaint or bitterness.
Makes no outward emotional display when realizing his blindness has returned, showing emotional restraint but not warmth.
Walks the path using counting steps and touching landmarks to navigate with little sight.
Stands still for a long time as the scene darkens and brightens with the sun, showing patience and calm awareness.
Realizes it's day after a long period of stillness and then uses his cane confidently to move on.
Returns fully blind yet manages to continue confidently, indicating adaptive skill.
Stands confidently at the podium speaking despite blindness, using dark glasses and cane as tools.
Works patiently and skillfully with three young blind children learning Braille.
Demonstrates situational awareness by sensing Amy’s presence after missing the trash can with his paper bag.
Misses the trash can by a large margin despite using his cane.
Expresses insightful understanding about perception beyond physical sight.
Smiles, nods, and gently takes Amy's arm as they walk off together.
